thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: $A down as greenback bounces

title: $A down as greenback bounces
text:
Thu, Jul 23, 2015, 5:36 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A down as greenback bounces AAP – 21 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar is lower against the greenback, which has snapped back on stronger US home sales data. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday, the currency was trading at 73.68 US cents, down from 74.17 cents on Wednesday. 
Americans bought homes in June at the fastest rate in more than eight years, pushing prices to record highs with buyer demand eclipsing the availability of properties on the market. 
CMC Markets chief analyst Ric Spooner said that although it had been a largely neutral day for the Aussie, the tone of trade had been softer. 
"The market is just looking for direction from the US dollar, which has started to weaken a little bit," he said. 
"If that develops into something more we could see support for the Aussie." 
Mr Spooner also noted that the Kiwi had held relatively firm on Thursday, despite a widely expected interest rate cut from the New Zealand Reserve Bank. 
RBNZ governor Graeme Wheeler cut the official cash rate a quarter point to three per cent and flagged more reductions were likely. 
"The fact that (the Kiwi) didn't fall, even after a rate cut, is just a symptom that the downward momentum in these commodity currencies has stopped, at least temporarily," Mr Spooner said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.36 Japanese yen, down from Wednesday's close of 91.75 yen, and at 67.39 euro cents, down from 67.70 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market is stronger following a modest rally overnight. 
IG chief market strategist Chris Weston said it had been a quiet day of trade. 
"There's nothing in the way of economic data worth focusing on and equity markets are fairly subdued as well," he said. 
"It's just trading with a lack of catalyst." 
Australian bond prices had a strong overnight session in which they outperformed US Treasuries. 
At 1630 AEST on Thursday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.105 (implying a yield of 2.895 per cent), up from 97.065 (2.935 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.030 (1.970 per cent), up from 98.000 (2.000 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Leaders take first step in GST changes AAP 
At the two-day gathering, the leaders agreed to broaden the GST to include overseas online transactions under $1000. …
